models.name: users
models.description:
User accounts and identities - This implements user identity, login, and account management as defined in the 'User Registration & Authentication' and 'User Profiles' requirements (05_detailed_functional_specifications.md, sec. 1). 

Stores essential user account data for login, session management, and regulatory compliance. For example, whenever a new user registers, a new record is created here. 

Key relationships: One-to-one with user_profiles, one-to-many with posts, threads, votes, reports, moderation_actions, notifications, bans, appeals, and user_preferences. 
Special behaviors: All usernames/emails are unique, passwords stored hashed, deleted_at supports GDPR/account removal workflow. Login/password change is tracked via timestamps.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each user record as required for identity and reference.

plainFields.name: email
plainFields.description:
User email address - Implements unique login requirement. 
Used for login, notification, and password recovery. Example: alice@example.com. Unique, required, and case-insensitive.

plainFields.name: username
plainFields.description: Display username chosen by user - Implements the unique identifier for visible user handles. Used in mentions, display, and profile URLs. E.g., 'policydebater'. Unique per system.

plainFields.name: password_hash
plainFields.description: BCrypt or scrypt hash of user password - Satisfies security and authentication requirements. Never stored in plain text. Used for authentication and reset flows. For example, a 60-character string from bcrypt.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Account creation timestamp - Auditing and registration flow. Used to track onboarding and compliance logs. E.g., 2025-05-30 03:00:00Z.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Last profile update timestamp - For tracking profile or credential changes. For example, security incident review. Always set by system.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp when account was soft-deleted - Satisfies GDPR/account removal/soft-delete. Used for audit and possible account recovery. Null if active, datetime if scheduled/removed.

plainFields.name: email_verified_at
plainFields.description: Time when email was verified - Implements requirements for registration verification and fraud prevention. Set after confirmation email. Null until verified.

plainFields.name: last_login_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of most recent login - Satisfies security/audit requirements. Used for last-seen and suspicious activity detection. Null if never logged in.

models.name: user_profiles
models.description:
Extended user profile information - This implements the extended profile specification from 'User Profiles' and 'User Preferences' requirements (05_detailed_functional_specifications.md, sec. 1 and 5).

Stores user bios, avatars, and optional public attributes. For example, controls public display in user lists and profile pages.

Key relationships: One-to-one with users (user_id unique), referenced in posts/threads as author_profile_id for display. Related to user_preferences.
Special behaviors: Bio, display_name, and avatar_url are optional. user_id unique and non-nullable. Data may be public depending on user preferences.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Uniquely identifies each profile record. One per user.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description:
Reference to parent user's {@link users.id}. 
Core to one-to-one profile linkage per 'User Profile' requirements. Must be unique and not null.

plainFields.name: display_name
plainFields.description: User-chosen display name - Implements profile extensibility, allowing nicknames/names separate from username. Null if not set. Used in public profile display.

plainFields.name: bio
plainFields.description: Profile biography/description - Implements detailed user information as desired. May contain markdown or plain text. Shown on profile pages. Null if unset.

plainFields.name: avatar_url
plainFields.description: Profile avatar image URL - Used for profile picture display. Supports privacy. Null if no image uploaded.

plainFields.name: location
plainFields.description: User's location - Implements optional extended profile data. Supports localization/geo features. Null if not set.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of profile creation - Used for onboarding and history analysis. Set automatically.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of last profile update - For audit and consistency with user table updates.

models.name: threads
models.description:
Discussion Thread - This implements the requirement for main topic containers from detailed functional specification Section 2 (Discussion Board Posting & Participation). 

Serves as the top-level unit for group conversations, roughly equivalent to a forum 'topic' or 'thread.' Users post new threads to start discussions. For example, a new thread on 'Recent elections and their economic impact.'

Key relationships: Each thread may have many posts ({@link posts}), is optionally categorized ({@link categories}), may be tagged ({@link thread_tags}), and tracks creator ({@link users}).
Special behaviors: Threads are never hard-deleted for audit; support soft deletion and visibility status.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each thread.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: Thread creator's {@link users.id}. Identifies the registered user who created the thread.

foreignFields.name: category_id
foreignFields.description: Thread's category {@link categories.id}. Categorizes threads into e.g., Politics, Economics. Nullable if thread not categorized.

plainFields.name: title
plainFields.description: Thread title - Implements the core need for discoverable conversation starters. For example, 'Election 2024: Fiscal Policy Debate.' Required for visibility in search/discovery. Cannot be null or empty.

plainFields.name: body
plainFields.description: Thread opening body - Implements content provision for the thread. Initial statement, question, or context for the discussion. For example, an introductory essay or main argument. Required.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Thread creation timestamp - Implements the requirement for chronological board history and auditing.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of last thread update - Used for sorting and audit trail. Updated on edits or moderation actions.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: If set, the thread is considered deleted (soft delete). Implements evidence preservation and moderation need to keep evidence instead of hard removal. Null if visible.

plainFields.name: is_pinned
plainFields.description: Indicates if thread is pinned (featured at top of category). Fulfills moderator requirements for content curation.

plainFields.name: is_locked
plainFields.description: If true, thread is locked and no new posts can be added. Used for moderation, compliance, or thread closure.

models.name: posts
models.description:
Thread Posts/Replies - Implements detailed specification Section 2, enabling user participation in discussion threads. 

A 'post' is a reply, comment, or argument within a thread. Posts are ordered chronologically within a thread. For example, a user replying with an analysis or question to the main topic.

Key relationships: Each post belongs to one thread ({@link threads}) and a user ({@link users}). Posts may be replies to other posts (self-referencing parent). Posts can link to multiple edits and votes.
Special behaviors: Nesting only one level deep (direct replies only). Posts are soft-deleted, not hard-deleted. Body text is stored in an immutable edit snapshot entity.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each post.

foreignFields.name: thread_id
foreignFields.description: Belonged thread's {@link threads.id}. Each post is associated with one main discussion thread.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: Author's {@link users.id}. Identifies which user wrote the post.

foreignFields.name: parent_id
foreignFields.description: Optional parent post's {@link posts.id}. Enables one-level reply structure (direct replies/quoting). Null if top-level reply to thread.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Post creation timestamp. For auditability and ordering.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description: When the post was last updated (usually due to edit or moderation).

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: If set, post is deleted (soft-deleted). Fulfills evidence preservation/review needs.

plainFields.name: reply_level
plainFields.description: Nesting depth. Enforces one-level nesting: 0 = thread reply, 1 = reply-to-post. For moderator enforcement.

models.name: votes
models.description:
Votes/Reactions - Implements requirements for community feedback and curation as found in the detailed specs (Voting & Engagement). 

Each vote represents a single user's upvote/downvote/like on a post. Prevents duplicate voting and tracks user engagement.

Key relationships: Every vote links to a user ({@link users}) and post ({@link posts}).
Special behaviors: Only one vote per user per post. Supports voting for ranking content by popularity. Used to prevent abuse and enable reactions.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique vote record.

foreignFields.name: post_id
foreignFields.description: Target post's {@link posts.id}. Each vote is cast on a specific post to indicate user sentiment.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: Voting user's {@link users.id}. User who cast the vote.

plainFields.name: vote_type
plainFields.description: Type of vote - Implements the requirement for user reactions. E.g., 'upvote', 'downvote', 'like', or potentially customized in future. Used for filtering, reporting, and analytics.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp when the vote was cast. Used for analytics and anti-abuse throttling policies.

models.name: post_edits
models.description:
Post Edit Snapshots - Implements the auditability and evidence preservation requirements outlined in the moderation and posting specs (Moderation, Compliance, Section 4). 

Each time a post is created or edited, a new snapshot record is created here. Enables audit trail, edit history, and rollback. For example, storing the original and each subsequent version of a post's content.

Key relationships: Each edit belongs to a post ({@link posts}) and a user ({@link users}) representing the editor. Used as immutable record for audit or legal review.
Special behaviors: Immutable after creation. Moderator-only access for some audit records.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique edit instance.

foreignFields.name: post_id
foreignFields.description: Target post's {@link posts.id}. Indicates which post this edit is a version of.

foreignFields.name: editor_user_id
foreignFields.description: User's {@link users.id} who made the edit. Set to original poster on first creation; later, may be a moderator or the original author on update.

plainFields.name: body
plainFields.description: Snapshot of post content at this edit. Implements evidence preservation and moderation needs. For example, showing pre- and post-edit differences.

plainFields.name: edit_reason
plainFields.description: Reason for edit, if provided. For transparency and complaint resolution â€” e.g., 'Typo correction', or moderator note.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: When edit snapshot was created. Used to order the edit history of each post, and for rollback/audit history logs.

models.name: thread_tags
models.description:
Thread Tags M:N Junction - Implements section 2 and 3 of the requirements for topic categorization, tagging, and content discovery (Search/Filtering). 

Enables tagging each thread with multiple tags. Junction entity for many-to-many between threads and tags.

Key relationships: Each record links a thread ({@link threads}) and a tag ({@link tags}).
Special behaviors: Unique constraint to prevent duplicate tags on a thread.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Junction record identifier.

foreignFields.name: thread_id
foreignFields.description: Target thread's {@link threads.id}.

foreignFields.name: tag_id
foreignFields.description: Target tag's {@link tags.id}. Enables tagging for topics, search filtering, and trending discovery.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: When the tag was linked to the thread. Useful for trending analysis.

models.name: moderators
models.description:
Moderators - This implements the "Moderator Management" requirements from section 4 (Moderation Tools, Compliance Principles) of the requirements analysis report.

This model tracks users with special privileges to moderate the board, enabling assignment, revocation, and identification of moderation powers. For example, when a user is promoted to moderator or demoted, a record is created/removed. 

Key relationships: Connects to the users table to indicate which user has moderator privileges. May relate to moderation_actions performed by this moderator. 
Special behaviors: Only designated users can access advanced moderation actions; enforce 1:1 relationship with the user entity.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for moderator assignment.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: Belonged user's {@link users.id}. Indicates which user is a moderator - implements the assignment of moderation privileges per user.

plainFields.name: assigned_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of when moderation privileges were granted - Implements audit and tracking needs. For example, assists compliance auditing.

plainFields.name: revoked_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp of when moderation privileges were revoked. Null if still active. Implements traceability requirements for role changes.

models.name: moderation_actions
models.description:
Moderation Actions - Implements the "Moderation Action Logging" and record-keeping requirements from section 4 (Moderation, Compliance, Record-Keeping) of the requirements report.

Records each moderation event/action (e.g., warning, post removal, ban, content edit) taken by a moderator. Enables audit trails, transparency, and the appeals process. For example, a moderator bans a user; the action is logged here.

Key relationships: Links to moderator, target user, possibly thread, post, or report. 
Special behaviors: Contains mandatory action type, reason, details, and references for appeal tracking.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for moderation action event.

foreignFields.name: moderator_id
foreignFields.description: Performing moderator's {@link moderators.id} - Links each action to the moderator who performed it, supporting auditability.

foreignFields.name: target_user_id
foreignFields.description: Target user's {@link users.id}. The user subject to moderation action. Implements compliance and history.

plainFields.name: action_type
plainFields.description: Type of moderation action taken (e.g., 'ban','warn','edit','remove_post'). Implements categorization support per requirements.

plainFields.name: action_detail
plainFields.description: Moderator's notes/details on reason. Provides business context for record keeping and appeals. Required for transparency.

plainFields.name: reference_id
plainFields.description: Reference entity ID (post/thread/report/ban/etc.), context sensitive. Implements traceability. Nullable for some actions.

plainFields.name: reference_type
plainFields.description: Reference entity type (e.g., 'post','thread','report','ban'). Enables tracking association to target entity, per requirements. Null when not applicable.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Time action was taken. Implements full moderation action logging/audit trail.

models.name: reports
models.description:
Reports - Implements the 'Reporting' and 'Flagging for Moderation' requirements detailed in section 4 (Moderation Tools, Functional Requirements) of the requirements report.

Represents each content report submitted by users concerning posts, threads, or users. Allows escalation to moderation actions. For example, a user flags a post as inappropriate and the incident is tracked here.

Key relationships: Links to the reporting user, optionally to the target user or reported post/thread, and to any resulting moderation_actions. 
Special behaviors: Each report logs its category, reason, handling status, and resolution time.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each user report.

foreignFields.name: reporter_id
foreignFields.description: User's {@link users.id} submitting the report. Implements traceability of report origins.

foreignFields.name: target_user_id
foreignFields.description: Target user's {@link users.id} reported in the case of user-based reports. Nullable for content reports.

plainFields.name: category
plainFields.description: Category of the report ('spam','abuse','misinformation','other'). Implements requirement for filtering and process prioritization.

plainFields.name: reason
plainFields.description: Detail/reason given for reporting. Supports clarification for moderation and record-keeping.

plainFields.name: reference_id
plainFields.description: Reference entity id (post/thread), supporting flexible reporting. Implements traceability. Nullable when not content oriented.

plainFields.name: reference_type
plainFields.description: Reference entity type ('post','thread','user'). Aids in content handling workflow. Nullable when not required.

plainFields.name: status
plainFields.description: Report handling status ('pending','in_review','resolved','dismissed') as described in moderation flow.

plainFields.name: handled_at
plainFields.description: Time when report was resolved/closed. Implements audit and compliance as per requirements; nullable if open.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Created time of report. Implements full moderation reporting audit trail.

models.name: bans
models.description:
Bans - Implements the 'Ban Users' and disciplinary requirements (moderation enforcement, transparency, appeals) in section 4 of the requirements.

Tracks each account ban, specifying user, moderator, duration, reason, and record for audit and appeals. For example, when a moderator bans a user, a new record is made and referenced by moderation_actions and possible appeals.

Key relationships: Connects to users (banned party) and moderators (actor). Can relate to appeals entities if contested. 
Special behaviors: Includes expiration, revoke/active flags, and timestamps; ensures auditability for all ban events.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each ban record.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: Banned user's {@link users.id}. Specifies party subject to ban enforcement.

foreignFields.name: moderator_id
foreignFields.description: Moderator's {@link moderators.id} who imposed the ban. Fulfills compliance and audit history needs.

plainFields.name: reason
plainFields.description: Reason for issuing the ban. Implements transparency, user notification, and support for appeals.

plainFields.name: expires_at
plainFields.description: Datetime for ban expiration (null if permanent). Implements business logic for temporary suspensions; per moderation specifications.

plainFields.name: revoked_at
plainFields.description: Datetime ban was lifted. Null if active. Implements audit and behavioral control; key for moderation workflows.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Time when ban was enacted. Required for full audit trail and reporting.

models.name: appeals
models.description:
Appeals - Implements the 'Appeals' process and moderation transparency mandates (section 4, compliance/principles) of the requirements analysis.

Tracks user appeals against disciplinary actions (e.g., bans, warnings). Enables due process, supports moderator/administrator review, and logs outcomes; for example, when a user contests a ban, an appeal is registered here for administrative review.

Key relationships: Connects to the appealing user, the related moderation_action or ban, and assigns moderators reviewing the appeal. 
Special behaviors: Tracks status, decision, all necessary compliance evidence. Any changes are recorded for accountability.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each appeal.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: Appealing user's {@link users.id} - the user who submits the appeal. Keeps audit and compliance integrity.

foreignFields.name: moderation_action_id
foreignFields.description: Target moderation_action's {@link moderation_actions.id}, i.e., the triggering disciplinary action. Implements the requirement for appeals to link to specific incidents.

foreignFields.name: ban_id
foreignFields.description: Target ban's {@link bans.id}, if the appeal relates to a ban. Implements clear referencing; nullable for warning-only appeals.

foreignFields.name: assigned_moderator_id
foreignFields.description: Assigned moderator's {@link moderators.id} handling the review of the appeal. For tracking accountability in due process; nullable until assigned.

plainFields.name: reason
plainFields.description: Reason provided for appeal - implements requirements for transparency, procedure, and full event context.

plainFields.name: status
plainFields.description: Appeal status ('pending','under_review','upheld','overturned'). Implements compliance for due process tracking.

plainFields.name: decision
plainFields.description: Moderator/admin's decision and rationale. Key for historical/audit reporting and user feedback. Nullable until resolved.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Time appeal was submitted. Implements compliance and process evidence requirements.

plainFields.name: resolved_at
plainFields.description: Time appeal was finalized/resolved. Null if still pending. For business tracking and audit.

models.name: notifications
models.description:
Notification Entity - This implements notification delivery and subscription requirements from the requirements analysis (Sections 4.5 and 5.5, plus Notification references in user journeys). 

Handles system- and user-generated notifications for in-app and email events across the forum: replies, mentions, thread subscriptions, moderation events, and so on. 
For example, when a user is mentioned in a post, or there is a reply in a subscribed thread, a notification record is created to alert the recipient.

Key relationships: refers to {@link users} (recipient), and links optionally to {@link posts} or {@link threads} when a notification is about specific content. Possible reference to {@link moderation_actions} for moderation event notifications.
Special behaviors: ensures unread/read status is tracked, supports batched sending and can store notification type and related context. Implements auditability of notification delivery. Prevents duplicate notifications for same event-recipient combination.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each notification.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description:
Notification recipient's {@link users.id} - Implements the requirement to target users for notifications.
Links the notification to its recipient. For example, the user who receives an alert for a reply or moderation action.

foreignFields.name: post_id
foreignFields.description:
Related post's {@link posts.id} - Implements notifications about replies/mentions/interactions on a specific post.
Nullable, since not all notifications are tied to a post.

foreignFields.name: thread_id
foreignFields.description:
Related thread's {@link threads.id} - Implements notifications related to thread-level events, e.g., subscription activity.
Nullable, since not all notifications are tied to a thread.

foreignFields.name: moderation_action_id
foreignFields.description:
Moderation action's {@link moderation_actions.id} - For notifications informing users about moderation events (warnings, bans, etc.).
Implements the transparency and moderation notice requirements. Nullable if not a moderation notification.

plainFields.name: type
plainFields.description:
Type of the notification - Implements the requirement to distinguish between notification event types (e.g., reply, mention, moderation, etc.).
For example, values might include 'reply', 'mention', 'mod_warning'. Critical for UI filtering and preference management.

plainFields.name: context
plainFields.description:
JSON-encoded context detail - Implements the requirement for contextual notification delivery.
Contains extra information (usernames, preview text, etc.) as JSON for flexible future extension.
Nullable, since not all notifications require extra context. For example, a simple upvote alert may require no additional context.

plainFields.name: delivered
plainFields.description:
Delivery status flag - Implements tracking if notification was already shown/pushed to the user.
For example, used to distinguish unread from read or pushed notifications in user interfaces.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description:
Creation timestamp - Implements audit trail and notification ordering requirements.
Indicates exactly when the notification was generated.

plainFields.name: read_at
plainFields.description:
Read timestamp - Implements the requirement to record when a user reads a notification (user journey: notification panel read tracking).
Nullable; is set only after the user actually views the notification. Used in unread/read badge logic.

models.name: user_preferences
models.description:
User Preferences Entity - Implements user-level preferences for notification delivery, as required in Sections 4.5 (User Preferences/Privacy) and 5.5.

Stores per-user notification settings (delivery medium preference, mute/block settings, frequency, language, etc).
For example, a user may prefer email for replies but only in-app for moderation events, and disable notifications for new followers.

Key relationships: connects to {@link users} (one-to-one).
Special behaviors: unique constraint on user_id ensures each user has one row. Supports extensible JSON-based preferences for additional options.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique row for the user's notification preferences.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description:
Belonged user's {@link users.id} - Implements the association between a user and their preferences.
One-to-one: Each user may have at most one preferences row.

plainFields.name: notification_settings
plainFields.description:
Notification settings as JSON - Implements storage for complex, customizable user notification preferences.
For example: delivery type (in-app/email/none) for various event types, daily digest settings, etc. Easily extended for future needs.

plainFields.name: language
plainFields.description:
Preferred language code (ISO format) - Implements user preference for localization/internationalization.
For example, 'en', 'ko', 'es'. Used to localize notifications and settings displays.

plainFields.name: mute_until
plainFields.description:
Datetime until notifications are suppressed - Implements temporary mute feature as required for user autonomy/privacy.
For example, users who want to temporarily pause alerts for a period. Nullable if not muted.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description:
Row creation timestamp - Implements audit trail for settings changes.
When the preference was set/created.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description:
Preferences update timestamp - Implements requirement to track last modification of user settings.
Used to manage and audit user-driven changes.

models.name: direct_messages
models.description:
Direct messaging entity - This implements the 'Private Messaging' feature detailed in section '04_functional_and_nonfunctional_requirements.md', supporting secure, private, and auditable direct communication between users.

Business explanation: Direct messages (DMs) enable users to privately communicate with each other without exposing their conversation in public threads. For example, a student privately contacts a policy expert to ask a question about economic indicators.

Key relationships: Each message is sent from a user (sender) to another user (recipient) via foreign keys. Optionally, messages may be linked to a certain topic or thread by future extension. DMs are only visible to the participants, not public or moderators.
Special behaviors: Messages are immutable upon sending; deleted/banned users retain message records for auditability, but future viewing is restricted. Soft delete is implemented to preserve audit evidence.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Each message has a unique UUID assigned at creation.

foreignFields.name: sender_id
foreignFields.description: Sender's {@link users.id} - The user who sends the direct message. Implements sender-recipient relationship as required for private messaging.

foreignFields.name: recipient_id
foreignFields.description: Recipient's {@link users.id} - The intended recipient of this message. Enables targeted delivery in the DM system.

plainFields.name: body
plainFields.description: Body content of the direct message - Implements requirement for private, secure exchange of information. Contains user-provided text. Example: 'Can you explain this thread more?'. Must remain confidential to only participants.

plainFields.name: sent_at
plainFields.description: Message sent timestamp - Implements messaging timestamping needed for sorting and audit trails. Example: '2025-05-30T09:15:00Z'. Cannot be null.

plainFields.name: read_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp if/when recipient reads the message - Supports notification/read status flows, as described in notifications specs. Null if unread.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description: Soft-deletion timestamp - Enables users to hide messages from their view while retaining audit and compliance evidence (e.g., flagged or abusive content). Null if not deleted.

models.name: blocked_users
models.description:
Blocked user relationship - Implements the 'User Preferences' and 'Privacy' requirements where a user can block another user from messaging them, as described in section '04_functional_and_nonfunctional_requirements.md'.

Business explanation: By blocking, a user prevents another user from sending them direct messages. For example, if User A is being harassed by User B, User A blocks User B to prevent further contact.

Key relationships: Many-to-one mappings (user blocks many others, and can be blocked by many). Requires unique sender-blocked pair per entry.
Special behaviors: Bidirectional blocks can exist. Block record persists for all historical DMs but only current blocks enforce prevention.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Uniquely identifies each user-to-user block instance.

foreignFields.name: blocker_id
foreignFields.description: Blocker's {@link users.id} - The user initiating the block. Implements one direction of user-to-user message restriction.

foreignFields.name: blocked_id
foreignFields.description: Blocked user's {@link users.id} - The user who is being blocked. Prevents messaging from this user to the blocker.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp when the block was enforced - Needed for audit and rollback ability. Example: '2025-05-30T10:05:00Z'.

plainFields.name: released_at
plainFields.description: Timestamp when the block was lifted or expired - Enables temporary blocks per policy. Null if still active.

models.name: categories
models.description:
[Discussion category management] - This implements the requirements for topic categorization and structured discussion organization, as referenced in Section 4 and 5 of the requirements analysis report.

Categories are used to organize threads into core subject areas (e.g., Politics, Economy, Local Affairs), enabling users to easily browse or filter discussion by topic. Category structure helps users find relevant threads efficiently and supports moderation by grouping posts with similar themes. For example, a thread about a new economic policy would be posted in the 'Economy' category.

Key relationships: threads (threads reference categories), moderators (categories can have associated moderators).
Special behaviors: Category names are unique; categories may be deactivated instead of deleted for audit/compliance.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each category.

plainFields.name: name
plainFields.description:
[Category name] - Implements user-facing topic naming from requirements.

Business meaning: The display name of the category (e.g., Politics, Economics).
Must be unique and concise. Used by users to navigate and filter discussions.

plainFields.name: description
plainFields.description:
[Category description] - Supports improved user experience and discoverability per requirements.

Business meaning: Short explanation of the category's purpose or focus. For example, 'Discussions related to political processes and governance.'
Displayed in UI to help users select correct categories.

plainFields.name: is_active
plainFields.description:
[Active flag for category] - Implements compliance and moderation/business process from requirements.

Business meaning: Whether the category is currently available for use. For example, set false instead of deleting for audit trail.
Soft-deletion for compliance.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description:
[Creation timestamp] - Implements the auditability and tracking requirements.

Business meaning: When the category was created. For example, used for sorting or for compliance audits.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description:
[Last update timestamp] - Implements system audit requirements.

Business meaning: Last time the category's info was edited. For example, when a category is renamed.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description:
[Soft deletion timestamp] - Implements moderation and compliance requirements by enabling audit trails instead of hard deletion.

Business meaning: When the category was marked as deleted/deactivated.
For example, a moderator disables a category but data remains for records.

models.name: tags
models.description:
[Discussion tag management] - This implements post and thread tagging features per Section 4 and 5 of the requirements analysis report.

Tags allow users to describe threads and posts with keywords or topics, enhancing content discoverability, filtering, and trending analysis. Tags may represent finer-grained topics than categories (e.g., 'Inflation', 'Elections', 'Fiscal Policy'). For example, a thread about monetary policy might use 'inflation' or 'central banks' tags.

Key relationships: thread_tags (for M:N relation with threads).
Special behaviors: Tag names are unique, lowercase, and may be soft-deleted.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each tag.

plainFields.name: name
plainFields.description:
[Tag name] - Implements tagging/discoverability requirements.

Business meaning: The tag's text, e.g., 'inflation', 'budget'.
Used for filtering, search, and analytics. Must be unique/lowercase.

plainFields.name: description
plainFields.description:
[Tag description] - Supports user UX/information needs from requirements.

Business meaning: Optional text describing the tag's intent, e.g., 'Posts about global financial inflation.'
Improves tag clarity and searchability.

plainFields.name: is_active
plainFields.description:
[Active flag for tag] - Implements moderation/compliance requirement for soft deletion.

Business meaning: Used to hide or restore tags without losing historical associations. For example, retired tags set to false/hidden.

plainFields.name: created_at
plainFields.description:
[Creation timestamp] - System audit support.

Business meaning: When the tag was created. Used in tag analytics and audit.

plainFields.name: updated_at
plainFields.description:
[Last update timestamp] - Audit requirement.

Business meaning: Last time the tag info was edited. For example, description updated.

plainFields.name: deleted_at
plainFields.description:
[Soft deletion timestamp] - Audit/compliance feature.

Business meaning: When the tag was marked as inactive/hidden for moderation or cleanup without loss of records.

models.name: activity_logs
models.description:
[User and System Activity Logging] - This implements the auditing and compliance requirements from Section 4.3 'Compliance & Moderation Principles' and the need for maintainability, monitoring, and traceability from Section 4.2 'Non-Functional Requirements' of the requirements document.

This model captures all significant user and system activities across the discussion board for purposes of audit, security monitoring, analytics, and troubleshooting. For example, when a user logs in, posts, edits a thread, votes, reports content, or receives moderation actions, a corresponding log entry is created.

Key relationships: References to involved user (optional, as some actions may be system-initiated) and, when applicable, associated content (post, thread, report, etc.).
Special behaviors: Designed for high write throughput, must retain records for compliance/audit purposes, only soft deletions for logs. Provides temporal traceability for all major platform events.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each activity log entry.

foreignFields.name: user_id
foreignFields.description: User's {@link users.id} who performed the activity. Nullable for system-initiated or anonymous actions. Implements stakeholder/auditing requirements for traceable accountability.

plainFields.name: event_type
plainFields.description:
[Type of activity event] - Implements audit and analytics requirement for identifying what action took place.

Business meaning: Describes the activity, e.g., 'login', 'post_create', 'vote', 'moderation_ban', 'edit', 'search', etc. For example, when a user votes on a post, the event_type is 'vote'.
Typically enumerated in application logic; enables reporting and filtering.

plainFields.name: target_entity
plainFields.description:
[Target entity affected] - Implements requirement for contextualizing what kind of object this log refers to.

Business meaning: Describes the domain object being acted upon, e.g., 'thread', 'post', 'user', 'report', etc.
For example, if a vote is cast on a post, the target_entity is 'post'.

plainFields.name: target_id
plainFields.description:
[Target object identifier] - Implements detailed activity tracking requirement.

Stores the unique ID of the thread, post, report, etc., this event is related to. For example, for a post edit, stores the edited post's id.
Enables cross-reference and look-up.

plainFields.name: description
plainFields.description:
[Optional detail or metadata] - Implements the requirement for providing more context in logs as outlined under Non-Functional Requirements and Moderation Principles.

Business meaning: Free-form or structured JSON/text with extra details, i.e., moderation reason, previous values, IP address, or serialized event context. For example, could store a JSON string with old/new values of a post edit.
Optional for events where no additional detail is necessary.

plainFields.name: occurred_at
plainFields.description:
[Timestamp of activity occurrence] - Implements traceability and compliance requirement for temporal event auditing (Section 4.3).

Stores the exact time this activity occurred, supporting analytics, investigation, and audit trails. For example, this helps reconstruct user actions sequence in case of a dispute.

models.name: mv_activity_log_counts_by_day
models.description:
[Materialized view of daily activity log counts] - Implements analytics and reporting requirements for monitoring engagement, detecting anomalies, and trend reporting, as specified in Section 4.2 'Non-Functional Requirements' (Performance, Analytics) and Section 3.4 'Expected Benefits'.

This model is a materialized view used to show the count of activity log events by day and event type. For example, used to plot daily login counts, posting rates, or moderation action frequency.

Key relationships: No direct foreign keys, but target_entity+event_type may map to application logic for drill-down analytics.
Special behaviors: Read-only, updated periodically via backend job. Enables dashboards and trend visualization for system administrators and moderators.

primaryField.name: id
primaryField.description: Primary Key. Unique identifier for each daily activity log count row.

plainFields.name: date
plainFields.description: [Day of the activity] - Implements daily aggregation for analytics reporting. Business meaning: Truncated to date (ignoring time part). For example, counts for 2025-04-01.

plainFields.name: event_type
plainFields.description:
[Type of aggregated event] - Implements reporting requirement for distinguishing between different types of user and system events per day.
Example values: 'login', 'post_create', 'vote', etc.

plainFields.name: count
plainFields.description:
[Aggregated count of events on the day] - Implements business need for daily metrics and analytics. Indicates total number of this event_type on this date. For example, how many logins on a given day.

Business meaning: Used to power admin dashboards and trend analysis.
